moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nc3 Qa5 4. d4 N:
The pinning move 5. .. Bg4 would put the question to the center indirectly. Continuing with 6. h3 Bh5 7. g4 prepares for a full scale King side assault.

The Main lines of the Mieses Variation follows 5 .. c6 6.Bc4 Bf5 7.Ne5 e6 8.g4 Bg6 9.h4 Nbd7 ... 1-0 (Viswanathan Anand - Joel Lautier, 1997), and
6.Ne5 Be6 7.Bd3 Nbd7 8.f4 g6 9.O-O Bg7 10.Kh1 Bf5 11.Bc4 e6 ... 1-0 (Kasparov - Anand, 1995).
moves.6. Bc4 e6 7. O-O Nbd7: This move leaves open the opening of the center with 8. .. c5.
moves.8. Bf4: Establishing control over the center and connecting the back row.
moves.8... c6: This move establishes firm control over the center with the minimum amount of force. This move suggests that Black is not going for the queenside castling.
moves.9. Bb3: This move protects the b-pawn while protecting the Bishop.
moves.9... Be7 10. h3 O-O 11. g4 Bg6 12. Re1: Moves the rook to the half open e file while minimizing the threat of exchanging off the knights.
moves.12... Nd5 13. Nxd5 cxd5 14. c3: The purpose of this move was to protect d4. However, c4 would have attacked the strengthened center at the cost of a isolated d pawn. The move seemed to be the lesser of a few evils.
moves.14... Rfe8 15. Bc2: Trying to weaken the area in front of the kingside while protecting the unprotected b pawn.
Still keeping an eye on the kingside.
moves.18... b4 19. cxb4: This move isolates the d pawn in addition to opening up the file.  The presence of a rook on c1 is in order.
moves.19... Qxb4 20. b3:
This move allows for the queen to hide while protecting the d and a pawns.
This overworking of a piece is perfect for a Zugzwang. Placing a rook on c1 was
called for, even at the cost of the a pawn following the inevitable rook exchange.
moves.20... Rec8 21. Qb2 Qc3 22. Qxc3 Rxc3: Black is established in the open file. The white king is forced into a passive role in the endgame. Notice that the kingside attack was never established.
moves.23. Kg2 Rac8: Doubling up on the open file. Notice that white's Bishop is totally out of action on the a1-h8 diagonal.
moves.24. Re3: Hoping to exchange the rooks and protect the isolated d-pawn with e3.
moves.24... Rc3c2 25. a4: Perhaps a3 followed by b4 would have been in order.
moves.25... Rd2: Preparing for Rcc2, attacking the weak f-pawn.
moves.26. Kf3: A series of errors begins at this point. The only thing keeping me from resigning is stubbornness.
